title: home
text:
I have a noisy brain. I’m also forgetful. In an attempt to organize that noise, and to help me remember things, I’ve started this website to share things that I find interesting.
Most musings will probably have a data science flavor, though I make no promises. This website is powered by coffee, so if you find any of this helpful and would like to support my work, consider buying me a coffee.
The animation on this page is of the collatz conjecture and was inspired by this visual.

title: how expensive is housing?
text:
WarningWork in Progress



I am actively updating this post. Content may change frequently as I work my way through this article.

title: how expensive is housing?
text:
national scale
The data we are using from the FRED:

CPIAUCSL: Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers: All Items in U.S. City Average
MSPUS: Median Sales Price of Houses Sold for the United States
MORTGAGE30US: 30-Year Fixed Rate Mortgage Average in the United States
MEHOINUSA646N: Median Household Income in the United States

A first look at the data:









What I need to do:

Put the data in the same time frequency (use time series models)

CPIAUCSL: monthly
MEHOINUSA646N: annual
MORTGAGE30US: weekly
MSPUS: quarterly

Forecast some series to match the most recent data point available. Account for uncertainty.



# A tibble: 4 × 3
  symbol        min_date   max_date  
  <chr>         <date>     <date>    
1 CPIAUCSL      1947-01-01 2025-11-01
2 MEHOINUSA646N 1947-01-01 2024-01-01
3 MORTGAGE30US  1971-04-02 2026-01-08
4 MSPUS         1963-01-01 2025-04-01


A look at the modeled data. Converted to a monthly frequency.5 Range examined from the max-min date (January, 1963) of the different series to the max date (January, 2026) of all the series.
5 Weekly frequency has been averaged. Annual and quarterly frequency linearly interpolated. No error estimates included in averaged/interpolated points.

# A tibble: 4 × 3
  symbol        min_date   max_date  
  <chr>         <date>     <date>    
1 CPIAUCSL      1963-01-01 2026-01-01
2 MEHOINUSA646N 1963-01-01 2026-01-01
3 MORTGAGE30US  1971-04-01 2026-01-01
4 MSPUS         1963-01-01 2026-01-01











Now, to build out the metrics:









What is the linear trend in the inflation adjusted median sales price of a home? Let’s exclude the forecast data:



Call:
lm(formula = ia2025_price ~ date, data = tb_msia %>% filter(combined_sd == 
    0))

Residuals:
   Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
-51402 -19898   1452  16631  64136 

Coefficients:
             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept) 2.104e+05  1.440e+03  146.13   <2e-16 ***
date        1.060e+01  1.310e-01   80.93   <2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 23550 on 746 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.8977,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.8976 
F-statistic:  6549 on 1 and 746 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16









From the above model, we find that real median sales price (2025 dollars) of a home has increased by $3,869.32 a year on average from January, 1963 to April, 2025.
For the monthly mortgage payment (30-year mortgage), we’ll assume a 20% down payment so the mortgage will 80% of the home value:









Now, let’s get the percentage of a person’s gross income that would go to their mortgage:
















Lastly, let’s look at the total cost of a house divided by the annual income:









Let’s build a model of the price/income ratio:



Call:
lm(formula = price_income_ratio ~ date, data = tb_final %>% filter(combined_sd == 
    0))

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-0.64244 -0.19255 -0.01162  0.18200  0.58437 

Coefficients:
             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept) 3.016e+00  1.495e-02  201.72   <2e-16 ***
date        1.132e-04  1.360e-06   83.19   <2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 0.2445 on 746 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.9027,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.9026 
F-statistic:  6921 on 1 and 746 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16









From the above model, we find that the ratio of the typical cost of a house to the typical household income has increased by 0.04 a year on average from January, 1963 to April, 2025.
